Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Infrastructures, Social Transformations and Resource Extraction in Contested Contexts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: This research investigates how social change occurs in communities economically dependent on the extraction of natural resources. Social scientists have found that areas with large deposits of natural resources are prone to conflict. Yet, as episodes of conflict garner news attention, less is known about the everyday ways that community members navigate the resource extraction infrastructures (security walls, shipping ports, conveyor belts) with which they live. This project investigates how communities make infrastructure a platform for demanding economic benefits, legal rights, and/or territorial control. It examines if and how these efforts, in turn, effect communitiesâ€™ economic and social wellbeing. Through a focus on extractive infrastructures, this project improves understandings of resources and societal change. In addition to providing training for a graduate student training in methods of scientific data collection and analysis, the findings will be valuable to policy researchers and policy makers interested in conflict resolution and natural resource extraction.<br/><br/>Research will be conducted in a community facing questions of who controls local natural resources in an effort to qualitatively understand how community members navigate infrastructures. Methods will include participant observation and rigorous documentation of (1) community life, daily work, and activities among these communities and (2) of the corporations carrying out the extraction. The doctoral student will augment these qualitative techniques with extensive formal and informal interviews, oral histories, media analysis, and archival research. By investigating how extractive infrastructure effects community members and how communities, in turn, engage those same infrastructures when demanding socio-economic change, this research generates critical knowledge of social change and conflict in resource rich regions.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project, carried out between December 2020 and October 2021 in Western Sahara and Morocco, examines how Sahrawis claim and mobilize the phosphates as a local-global resource to negotiate the violence exercised on them by the Moroccan state. The fieldwork involved research in a political context marked by the return to armed combat from the Saharawi refugee camps and mobility restrictions due to the COVID-19 pandemic that made entering the militarized city of Laayoune difficult. Research activities included participant observation with local families involved in the phosphates industry either through direct employment or labor union struggles to receive social benefits granted through the Spanish welfare system when they occupied Western Sahara until 1975. In addition, I conducted interviews and oral histories with an extensive range of social and political actors, including phosphates laborers, technicians, unemployed youth, agricultural industrialists, merchants, smugglers, and state authorities. Moreover, activities included daily participant observation and on-the-go interviews with women in intimate living spaces, thereby informing the research with insights from spaces off-limits to researchers in this area. The research also included a collection of personal and family archives of documents related to employment, writings, photographs, a collection of media press releases, newspaper clips, and public reports.

 

Project findings provide insights into the perceptions and practices that shape the phosphates landscape and its relationship to the prolonged conflict. Workers at the phosphates compound draw upon their work in repairing and maintaining the extractive infrastructure, such as the conveyor belt that transports raw phosphates from the extraction site to the phosphates compound. Saharawi laborers work in various positions, such as overseeing the equipment that washes raw phosphates, the machinery that loads phosphates onto cargo ships, repairing the conveyor belt, driving the cranes, and setting up the explosives to open mining pits. From their various labor positions, Saharawis work for the upkeep of the industry that subjugated them to a colonial project they denounced. At the same time, they challenge their subjugation by using their labor positions to document waste, pollution, and plundering of natural resources. This documentation was the subject of international news. It led on a few occasions to the seizure of phosphates cargo ships when they entered ports of countries that support the Saharawi nationalist stance.

 

Research findings indicate that labor positions at the phosphates company offer alternative political engagements with the nationalist struggle, which valued the ability to capture and document information related to Morocco?s illegal exploitation of phosphates. This simultaneously devalued other political actions and reshaped the Saharawi political project in terms of what local communities coined ?the natural resources war.? Even when it highlighted Saharawi subjugation to occupation, employment at the phosphates company also reworked what exploitation means. Saharawis perceive their participation in the illegal exploitation and plundering of natural resources as a political and ethical deferral of the occupation. Saharawi families see their labor for the occupation to provide them with political opportunities, such as documenting cargo ships without resorting to violence. Saharawi efforts to document the plundering allowed the Saharawi political leadership to win a legal battle at the European Union Justice Court. The legal team used data, photographs, and testimonials that Saharawi laborers in Laayoune produced. Saharawi workers also reveal how the infrastructure of the phosphates deteriorates at high speed due to the harsh environmental conditions and lack of Moroccan mechanical upgrades. Ethnographic accounts trace how political projects and affiliations are produced, maintained, and undermined in a longstanding political dispute defined by competing sovereignties expressed through the struggle to seize control over the critical extractive infrastructure.

 

Interviews and oral histories revealed that political commitment to the national struggle defined the politics of households. Households in Laayoune are marked by the phosphates' labor politics, militant trajectories, and colonial histories. The phosphates household epitomized the nationalist struggle and further shaped gender dynamics, social solidarity, and political commitments among Saharawi families. Research findings indicate that Saharawi engagement with the extractive regime transformed gender and gendered power. Saharawis led a long labor battle in which they negotiated with the Moroccan state to gain their social and labor benefits. During these negotiations, the Moroccan state offered Saharawi families the possibility to employ either a son or daughter of an ex-laborer of Saharawi origin. This differed from the original Spanish phosphates company contract in which laborers were guaranteed the employment of one of their sons upon their retirement. The Moroccan offer created gender turbulence among Saharawi households. Research findings show the effects of phosphates regimes and how it transforms local social and gender relations. By looking at the relationship between extractive infrastructure, labor histories, and households, this research demonstrates that extractive infrastructure has generated new political means for Saharawis to engage with resource sovereignty from different scales and places, making the phosphates a resource and commodity of multiple meanings, contingencies, and futures.
